Mathias Johansson & Gemini

title: Repositories
text:
kb-trend


This is a tool for extracting trendlines for sesarches in the National Library of Sweden’s (Kungliga Biblioteket; KB) search API. It comes in two variants, firtsly is the python implementation published on PyPI and therefore pip-installable. This tool is able to perform a battery of queries to create aggregated and disaggregated timelines. The second is a much simpler form, which is a SPA (Single Page Application) hosted as a static site on GitHub. This version performs a single query at a time and produces a downloadable .csv file of the data and relevant metadata – such as the full URL of the query.





2025-12-18












 ToK reader


This is a JavaScript based tool for reading exchanges of utterances from the swedish parliamentary debates for the Tal om Kvinnor project. The material is retrieved from the SWERIK project and has been pre processed in preparation for this reader, namely:

The corpus has been segmented into individual utterances.
Speaker party and gender are in the utterance-level metadata.
Utterances have been tagged with categories relevant for the research project.
The corpus has been split into one file per year, from 1900-1940 (the period under study).

The files are hosted next to the code that prepared them – and each year’s file is loaded into the reader as the user reaches that year. In this way the data becomes searchable, readable and browsable – accessible – to people without having to wrangle with .xml files. However, searches are limited to a single year at a time.





2025-12-10












 Journal Digital Corpus - Reader


A javascript based SPA (Single Page Application) for exploring and reading the timestamped Journal Digital Corpus right in the browser. This is hosted as a static website on GitHub and loads the publicly available corpus into the user’s browser to make it readable and searchable. It can also produce stable URLs with seach queries and selected results. This way it is possible to create a permanent bookmark to a specific part of a specified version of the corpus.





2025-11-22












 Journal Digital Corpus - Map


A javascript based tool for exploring the geographical dimensions of the Journal Digital Corpus.





2025-10-16












 stum


A tool for extracting intertitle-texts from Swedish newsreels.





2025-06-02












 SweScribe


Tool for automatic speech recognition of Swedish newsreels.





2025-06-02












 sca


This is a python + sqlite implementation of the method Structural Collocation Analysis as described in Structural reading: Developing the method of Structural Collocation Analysis using a case study on parliamentary reporting and used in Democracy (Not) on Display: A Structural Collocation Analysis of the Mother of All Parliaments’ Reluctance to Broadcast Herself





2025-05-23


Mathias Johansson












 Personal Planerare


A javascript based SPA (Single Page Application) for planning ratios between teaching and research at the Department of Arts and Cultural Sciences.





2024-10-03












 freewrite


A textual-powered application for freewriting.





2024-01-02












 CITADEL


CITADEL (plaCename dIsambiguaTion AnD gEocoding appLication) is a toponym disambiguation tool developed during the course of the article Historical GIS and Guidebooks





2022-12-16


Mathias Johansson & Sune Bechmann Pedersen

title: A Fugue on Thinking Machines
text:
A few weeks ago I started playing around with Google’s AI-Studio and Gemini.app trying to test the limits of their public AI-systems can do. Among the experiments were a series of disappoinging attempts to make it produce code and a lot of amusement generating images and videos. I also gave it’s ‘research’ mode a spin which, unlike the code-generation and image-generation, requires very little effort in the way of prompt-engineering to produce decent results. You tell it to ‘research’ a topic (or topics), it presentes a plan of investigation (which you can influence further) and 20-30 minutes later you have your own wikipedia-like report (with less reliability). What impressed me the most was how neatly it can be used on my phone, once it starts ‘researching’ I can close down the app and get a notification when the report is ready (Not so for the other modes). This means that I can play around with it before I walk somewhere and by the time I am there, I have something to new to read!
However, if I close down the app I do not get to see the number of ‘researched’ sources tick upwards. Which is part of my fascination with the process; it gives me a metric to target as I play around with it. Not only can you see how many sources (sites) it searches, a selection of these sources are also included as references in the report. To me, this is like having my own personalized pesudo-Wikipedia-article generator. Only, less reliable, worse prose, without images diagrams and links to other articles. But, it is a lot more flexible and a lot more convenient. It can be used similarly to how I tend to use Wikipedia: Get a basic understanding for some topic and gather further resources to read further.
Besides the high dubiousness-level (technical term) of the fact checking, the prose tends to be very boring and bland. It has a tendency to over-summarise and sometimes over-explain simple information (based on my limited experiments). So, I decided to attempt to make the prose more entertaining. Specifically, to mimic the style of Douglas Hofstadter’s fugues in Gödel, Escher, Bach.
Hofstadter’s fugues manage to be downright entertaining despite dealing with abstract and complex ideas. So, I instructed Gemini to mimic this style while explaining the ascent of AI. A secondary motive for picking this topic was to produce a text or a case that I could use in teaching. At worst the output would be nonsense and therefore an interesting case to discuss, OR it would create a decent instructive overview. Either way, it had the potential to be both entertaining and useful. Having picked the topic, picking the two main discussants remained. Being lazy, I went with to of my default personas for an LLM to impersonate: Edgar Allan Pie and William Shakespeare – specifying that more temporary characters can be introduced as needed.
The result was an 8,00 word report based on 167 ‘researches’ websites out of which 124 were cited in the report! Two personal records right there! In total the report includes 7 fugues, and a prelude (included below). I must admit that I have to date only read the preamble and the overviews (of which there are two in the report!), but so far I am satisfied and entertained. Quite frankly, the most disappointing part of the report is that it ends with the release of Chat-GPT; sure it was an important event, but a lot of interesting things have happened since then!

title: A Fugue on Thinking Machines
text: /MJ

title: A Fugue on Thinking Machines
section: Prelude: A Midnight Dreary, A Question Airy
text:
Prelude: A Midnight Dreary, A Question Airy
SCENE:
A dimly lit study, overflowing with books and arcane instruments.
EDGAR ALLAN POE sits hunched over a desk, quill in hand,
the flickering candlelight casting long, dancing shadows.

The hour is late.
POE:
(Muttering to himself)
Once upon a midnight dreary, while I pondered, weak and weary,
Over many a quaint and curious volume of forgotten lore—
Not of demons, nor of ravens tapping at my chamber door,
But of intellect—that spectral architect of thought,
Its ghostly gears and levers, how a notion might be wrought
From the ether of the mind, a phantasm given form.
This engine in the skull, that conjures calm and storm,
Is it a sacred fire, a uniquely human spark?
Or can its essence be distilled, to animate the dark
And silent artifice of man, a mimicry of soul?
To cede to brass and wire, our intellectual control?
(WILLIAM SHAKESPEARE enters, a knowing glimmer in his eye.
He carries a folio, perhaps of his own works.)
SHAKESPEARE:
Good Master Poe, still wrestling with the shades of night?
Your brow is furrowed deep, as if by some internal fight.
What phantoms vex thee now? Is it the muse, that fickle sprite,
Or some new terror of the soul, that shuns the morning's light?
POE:
Ah, good Will. 'Tis not the muse, but a query yet more dire.
This "stuff that dreams are made on," as your Prospero did conspire
To name our fleeting thoughts – this power to reason and to feel,
Is it a gift divine, or something we might steal,
Or rather, replicate, in constructs of our own design?
Could mind itself be patterned, line by intricate line,
Like verse, or like the workings of some complex, ticking clock?
The ancients whispered of such things, a brazen head to talk,
Or clockwork men that moved and mimicked life's display.
A fancy, then.
But now… new arts hold sway.
SHAKESPEARE:
Indeed, a timeless yearning! Since first we learned to frame
Our thoughts in words, we've sought to give intelligence a name
And form beyond ourselves. To breathe a semblance of our wit
Into the clay, the wood, the metal. Is it not writ
Across the ages, this desire to see our image cast
Not just in flesh and blood, but in creations built to last,
And, peradventure, think? This grand ambition, to my eye,
Sets a most curious stage for dramas yet to fly From human ingenuity.
The play's the thing, you see,

And this new act, though strange, holds potent mystery.
The human mind, a universe of wonder and of dread,
Has long been fascinated by the thought of raising from the dead,
Or rather, from the inert, a mind not born but made.
This is no fleeting whim, but a foundation deeply laid
In our collective soul. The very urge to understand our own
Intricate mental workings, pushes us toward the unknown,
To see if such a marvel can be mirrored, piece by piece.
This long-held fascination, this intellectual unease,
Provides the fertile ground from which the seeds of what they call
"Artificial Intelligence" would rise, to stand or fall.
POE:
A fertile ground, perhaps, for wonders, or for woes untold.
Let us then trace this "red thread," as the story starts to unfold.

title: Repositories
text:
SWINNO v3.0.0


Database of Swedish Innovations


SWINNO is a database of Swedish innovations constructed with the LBIO method by a research project by the same name. The dataset has been gathered and constructed since 2010 by a several researchers and assistants (I have been one of them), and had been published several times in an .xlsx format.
In this series of releases I tried to create a user-friendly dataset that retains as much of the relational-structure of the FileMaker database in a user friendlier format (SQLite3). The release is a scaled down version that does away with all the the sensitive data and controls necessary for constructing the data but not necessary for using it . In more recent versions this repository also contain he original format (.xlsx) – included since in the latest release – and publishes a scaled down version of the original FileMaker database as a SQLite3 database and each table is in a separate .csv file. Metadata is published separately as a living-codebook.





Jan 31, 2024












 Journal Digital Corpus





A corpus of the speech and intertitles of the Swedish Newsreel archive Journal Digital. Created with SweScribe and stum.





Jun 5, 2025












 UK Hansard 1935-2014


A metadata enriched version of the Hansard corpus


One of the outputs from Betto van Waarden’s Marie Skłodowska-Curie project “Presenting Parliament: Parliamentarians’ visions of the communication and role of parliament within the mediated democracies of Britain, Belgium and the Netherlands, 1844-1995.”





Nov 24, 2022












 Audiovisual Analysis of Journal Digital





Derrived from Journal Digital collections in order to perform analyzes temporal co-occurrences of audio and visual features in videos:

Audio extraction : Uses MIT’s Audio Spectrogram Transformer (AST) to classify audio content
Visual extraction : Uses Moondream vision model for object detection in frames
Pairing analysis : Identifies audio-visual co-occurrences with temporal alignment
Temporal analysis : Tracks changes in audio-visual patterns across years

Structure

src.zip : The source code for the library
results.zip : The .csv outputs
moon_results.tar.gz : Results from the Visual extraction pipeline
audio_results.tar.gz : Results forom the Audio extraction pipeline






Jan 2, 2026












 Geographical Analysis of Journal Digital





Derrived from Journal Digital Corpus in order to perform a geographical analysis of Swedish newsreels from the Journal Digital corpus (1930-1965) using Named Entity Recognition (NER), geolocation validation, and geocoding. The pipeline extracts location mentions from video subtitles, validates them against the GeoNames gazetteer, and converts them to geographic coordinates using Nominatim. Results include validated location datasets, temporal analysis of geographic mentions, regional distribution statistics, and JSON exports for spatial visualization. The project provides tools for preprocessing NER data, analyzing location patterns over time, and generating interactive visualizations of geographic coverage in Swedish newsreel production.





Jan 2, 2026












 Historical GIS and Guidebooks:


Czechoslovak Tourist Attractions


A dataset of geolocated travel guide toponyms, compiled in the process of a research project Historical GIS and Guidebooks: A Scalable Reading of Czechoslovak Tourist Attractions (Bechmann Pedersen & Johansson, forthcoming) in which we performed a scalable reading of three travel guides of the former Czechoslovak lands as they were cirka 1959. We used a specialized, open-sourced tool CITADEL created for this project, which in itself relies on open-sourced data from GeoNames and WikiData.





Nov 24, 2022












 Supplementary material to ‘Automatic Identification of Hate Speech – A Case-Study of Alt-Right YouTube Videos’





Supplementary material for the article Supplementary material to ‘Automatic Identification of Hate Speech – A Case-Study of Alt-Right YouTube Videos’. The dataset is restricted due to the sensitive nature of its contents: Transcriptions gathered from YouTube which we have processed with a classifier trained to detect hate speech.





Jan 8, 2024





No matching items
